poem:
Title: "Margate Mornings, a Transforming Tale"

In Margate's windy wake, a Victorian shade,
Drinking dawn from Café Louie's cup, seafront laid.
Sunset's whispers paint Turner's halls, within sight,
Crafted flavours dance on Margate's changing night.
Demographics shift as tides, food scenes wane and wax,
Yet, the allure of the wine bar, Parisian, never lax.
Why do I not tread here more? A question only the sea can answer.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sète, Margate, Kent: ‘They’ve completely nailed the Parisian wine bar vibe’ – restaurant review | Grace Dent on restaurants February in blowy Margate, and I enjoyed the seafront like a convalescing Victorian, drank coffee at the new Cafe Louie on Sea at the Turner Contemporary, savoured a dreamy sunset and wondered why I didn’t come here more often. Margate’s demographic and its food scene may have shifted a fair bit over the past decade, but". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Sète, Margate, Kent: ‘They’ve completely nailed the Parisian wine bar vibe’ – restaurant review | Grace Dent on restaurants February in blowy Margate, and I enjoyed the seafront like a convalescing Victorian, drank coffee at the new Cafe Louie on Sea at the Turner Contemporary, savoured a dreamy sunset and wondered why I didn’t come here more often. Margate’s demographic and its food scene may have shifted a fair bit over the past decade, but
